verses.text: Hear this, O house of Jacob, you who are called by the name of Israel, and who came out from the waters of Judah, who swear by the name of the Lord and invoke the God of Israel—but not in truth or in righteousness.
verses.comment: God addresses the people of Israel, highlighting their outward religious identity but insincerity of heart. The imagery of 'waters of Judah' points to covenant and lineage. Jesus later confronts similar hypocrisy in Matthew 15:8.

verses.text: For they call themselves after the holy city and rely upon the God of Israel—the Lord of hosts is his name.
verses.comment: The people claim connection to the holy city (Jerusalem) and the Lord, but their trust is only nominal. This echoes the call for authentic worship in John 4:23-24.

verses.text: The former things I declared long ago; they went out from my mouth and I made them known; then suddenly I did them, and they came to pass.
verses.comment: God confirms His sovereignty by declaring and fulfilling past prophecies. Fulfilled prophecy is a key sign of divine truth, later emphasized by Jesus (Luke 24:44).

verses.text: Because I knew that you are obstinate, and your neck is an iron sinew, and your forehead is bronze,
verses.comment: Stubbornness here is linked to sin and lack of repentance. Just as Israel was stubborn, so all believers are called to ongoing conversion and humility (Rom. 2:5).

verses.text: So I declared them to you from of old, before they came to pass I announced them to you, lest you say, 'My idol did them, my carved image and my cast figure commanded them.'
verses.comment: God reveals the future to prevent attributing His works to idols. This stresses the exclusivity of true worship, a theme continued into the New Testament (Acts 17:29-31).

verses.text: You have heard; now see all this, and will you not declare it? From this time I announce to you new things, hidden things that you have not known.
verses.comment: God's progressive revelation here foreshadows the unfolding mystery clarified in the New Testament (Eph. 3:3-6). God's revelation continues in the Church throughout history.

verses.text: They are created now, not long ago; before today you have never heard of them, lest you should say, 'Behold, I knew them.'
verses.comment: New acts of God cannot be claimed by Israel to be their insight. This anticipates God acting in unexpected ways, fulfilled supremely in Christ (Rom. 16:25-26).

verses.text: You have never heard, you have never known, from of old your ear has not been opened. For I knew that you would surely deal treacherously, and that from birth you were called a rebel.
verses.comment: God diagnoses deep-seated human sinfulness. This underscores the necessity of grace and transformation—a theme picked up in John 3:3-6.

verses.text: For my name's sake I defer my anger, and for the sake of my praise I restrain it for you, so that I do not cut you off.
verses.comment: God's mercy is not based on human merit, but for the sake of His glory—a forerunner to New Testament soteriology (Rom. 3:25-26). The faithful remnant motif is seen here and later in Romans 11:5.

verses.text: Behold, I have refined you, but not as silver; I have tested you in the furnace of affliction.
verses.comment: Purification through suffering is a key biblical theme. God's disciplinary tests are always for restoration (see Heb. 12:6-7). The process of sanctification is lifelong.

verses.text: For my own sake, for my own sake, I do it, for how should my name be profaned? My glory I will not give to another.
verses.comment: The centrality of God's glory aligns with the call for worship in spirit and truth. Jesus as the true revelation of God's glory (John 1:14) fulfills this promise.

verses.text: Listen to me, O Jacob, and Israel, whom I called: I am He; I am the first, and I am the last.
verses.comment: God’s unique, eternal nature is declared here. Jesus directly applies this title to Himself in Revelation 1:17-18, showing His divinity.

verses.text: My hand founded the earth, and my right hand spread out the heavens; when I call to them, they stand forth together.
verses.comment: God’s creative power is highlighted. The New Testament ascribes creation to Christ as the Logos (John 1:3; Col. 1:16).

verses.text: Assemble, all of you, and listen: Who among them has declared these things? The Lord loves him; he shall perform his purpose on Babylon, and his arm shall be against the Chaldeans.
verses.comment: God's chosen deliverer (Cyrus, typologically Christ) will fulfill God's will. This is a shadow of Christ's total victory over evil (Col. 2:15).

verses.text: I, even I, have spoken; yes, I have called him, I have brought him, and he will prosper in his way.
verses.comment: God alone calls and establishes His instruments. The theme of vocation and anointing is fulfilled ultimately in Christ, who is perfectly obedient to the Father (John 5:30).

verses.text: Draw near to me, hear this: from the beginning I have not spoken in secret, from the time it came to be I have been there. And now the Lord God has sent me, and His Spirit.
verses.comment: Here is a hint of the mystery of God’s unity and distinction—the Sender, the Sent, and the Spirit. This verse has long been seen as a veiled reference to the plurality within God, a theme revealed fully in the New Testament Trinity (Matt. 28:19).

verses.text: Thus says the Lord, your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel: 'I am the Lord your God, who teaches you to profit, who leads you in the way you should go.'
verses.comment: God acts as Redeemer (Goel), guiding His people. The motif of divine teaching anticipates Christ as Teacher and Redeemer (Luke 24:27).

verses.text: Oh, that you had paid attention to my commandments! Then your peace would have been like a river, and your righteousness like the waves of the sea;
verses.comment: Blessings are connected to obedience. Jesus, the fulfiller of the Law, brings true peace and righteousness by uniting commandment and forgiveness (Matt. 5:17-18; John 14:27).

verses.text: your offspring would have been like the sand, and your descendants like its grains; their name would never be cut off or destroyed from before me.
verses.comment: Refers back to the Abrahamic promise. Continuity of God’s people is guaranteed by His faithfulness, ultimately realized in the perpetual community of faith (Matt. 16:18).

verses.text: Go out from Babylon, flee from Chaldea, declare this with a shout of joy, proclaim it, send it out to the end of the earth; say, 'The Lord has redeemed his servant Jacob!'
verses.comment: The redemption from Babylon prefigures the greater redemption in Christ. This call to leave exile has spiritual meaning too—the call to holiness and separation from sin (2 Cor. 6:17).

verses.text: They did not thirst when he led them through deserts; he made water flow for them from the rock; he split the rock and the water gushed out.
verses.comment: This alludes to God’s miraculous provision in the wilderness, which Paul later interprets as a type of Christ, the spiritual Rock who gives living water (John 7:37).

verses.text: 'There is no peace,' says the Lord, 'for the wicked.'
verses.comment: This warning underscores the necessity of repentance and perseverance. True peace is found only in union with God, upheld and mediated through the ongoing worship and sacramental life of the Church.
